description: Mechanics liens, contract types, licensing requirements, business law

questions.question: Which type of contract establishes a fixed total price for the entire project?
questions.explanation: A lump sum or stipulated sum contract establishes a fixed total price for the complete scope of work. The contractor assumes the risk for cost overruns.

questions.question: In a cost-plus contract, the contractor is reimbursed for:

options.text: Actual costs plus an agreed fee or percentage

questions.explanation: A cost-plus contract reimburses the contractor for actual documented costs of labor, materials, and equipment, plus an agreed-upon fee or percentage for overhead and profit.

questions.question: Which contract type is best suited for projects where the scope cannot be precisely defined?
questions.explanation: Time and materials contracts are used when the scope of work is uncertain. The owner pays for actual labor hours and materials with an agreed markup.

questions.question: A unit price contract is most appropriate for:

options.text: Projects with repetitive work and uncertain quantities

questions.explanation: Unit price contracts set prices per unit of work (cubic yard of concrete, linear foot of pipe). They're ideal when quantities are uncertain but unit costs can be established.

questions.question: What are the four essential elements required to form a valid construction contract?
questions.explanation: A valid contract requires: (1) an offer, (2) acceptance of that offer, (3) consideration (exchange of value), and (4) legal capacity of the parties to contract.

questions.question: What is 'consideration' in a construction contract?

options.text: The time to consider the contract
Something of value exchanged between parties

questions.explanation: Consideration is the exchange of value that makes a contract legally binding. In construction, this is typically the promise to perform work in exchange for payment.

questions.question: In a typical construction contract, which document takes precedence when there is a conflict?

options.text: The agreement or supplementary conditions typically take precedence

questions.explanation: Contract documents usually establish an order of precedence. Typically: agreement, supplementary conditions, general conditions, specifications, then drawings. This is stated in the contract.

questions.question: What document contains the general terms and conditions that apply to all bidders?
questions.explanation: Instructions to Bidders outline requirements for preparing and submitting bids, including bid security, withdrawal procedures, and award criteria.

questions.question: A change order is:

options.text: An informal request for additional work
A written order signed by owner and contractor changing the contract

questions.explanation: A change order is a written document signed by both owner and contractor authorizing changes to the work, contract price, or contract time.

questions.question: Who typically initiates a Construction Change Directive (CCD)?
questions.explanation: A Construction Change Directive is issued by the owner (often through the architect) directing changes before agreement on cost adjustment is reached. It allows work to proceed while costs are negotiated.

questions.question: What should a contractor do BEFORE performing extra work requested by the owner?

options.text: Complete the work and invoice later
Obtain a signed change order or written directive
Add it to the final billing

questions.explanation: Contractors should always obtain written authorization before performing extra work to ensure payment and avoid disputes. This protects both parties.

questions.question: What is retainage in construction?

options.text: A percentage of payment withheld by the owner until completion

questions.explanation: Retainage is a percentage (typically 5-10%) of each progress payment withheld by the owner as security until the project is substantially complete.

questions.question: At what point is retainage typically released?

options.text: When all change orders are signed
At substantial completion or final completion

questions.explanation: Retainage is typically released at substantial completion or final completion, after all punch list items are addressed and required documentation is submitted.

questions.question: What is 'substantial completion'?

options.text: When the work can be used for its intended purpose
When the final payment is made
When the certificate of occupancy is issued

questions.explanation: Substantial completion is when the work is sufficiently complete that the owner can occupy or use it for its intended purpose. Minor punch list items may remain.

questions.question: What typically begins at substantial completion?
questions.explanation: The warranty period typically begins at substantial completion, not at final completion. This is when the owner takes beneficial use of the project.

questions.question: What does a bid bond guarantee?

options.text: The contractor will complete the work
The contractor will enter into a contract if awarded the bid
The work will be free of defects

questions.explanation: A bid bond guarantees that the bidder will enter into a contract at the bid price if awarded. If the bidder refuses, the surety pays the difference to the owner.

questions.question: What does a performance bond guarantee?

options.text: The contractor will submit the lowest bid
The contractor will complete the work per the contract
The project will be completed on time

questions.explanation: A performance bond guarantees the contractor will complete the work according to the contract. If the contractor defaults, the surety arranges for completion.

questions.question: What does a payment bond protect?
questions.explanation: A payment bond guarantees that subcontractors, suppliers, and laborers will be paid. This protects the owner from liens by ensuring lower-tier parties are paid.

questions.question: What are the three parties to a surety bond?
questions.explanation: A surety bond involves three parties: the principal (contractor) who is bonded, the obligee (owner) who is protected, and the surety (bonding company) that guarantees performance.

questions.question: What type of insurance protects against claims for bodily injury and property damage to third parties?
questions.explanation: Commercial General Liability (CGL) insurance covers third-party bodily injury and property damage claims arising from construction operations.

questions.question: What type of insurance covers damage to the project during construction?
questions.explanation: Builder's risk insurance covers damage to the building under construction from fire, theft, vandalism, and other covered perils.

questions.question: Workers' compensation insurance is:

options.text: Required by law in most states

questions.explanation: Workers' compensation insurance is required by law in virtually all states. It covers medical expenses and lost wages for work-related injuries regardless of fault.

questions.question: What is a mechanics lien?

options.text: A legal claim against property for unpaid construction work
A license to perform mechanical work

questions.explanation: A mechanics lien (also called construction lien or materialman's lien) is a legal claim that can be placed against property when contractors, subcontractors, or suppliers are not paid.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a preliminary notice (pre-lien notice)?

options.text: To preserve the right to file a lien later

questions.explanation: A preliminary notice notifies the property owner that a subcontractor or supplier is working on the project and preserves their right to file a lien if not paid.

questions.question: What must typically happen before a mechanics lien can be filed?

options.text: The claimant must provide labor, materials, or services that improve the property

questions.explanation: To file a valid mechanics lien, the claimant must have provided labor, materials, or services that permanently improved the real property.

questions.question: What is a lien waiver?

options.text: A requirement to file a lien
A document releasing lien rights in exchange for payment
A notice of intent to file a lien

questions.explanation: A lien waiver is a document signed by a contractor, subcontractor, or supplier relinquishing their right to file a lien, usually in exchange for payment.

questions.question: What are the two main types of lien waivers?
questions.explanation: Lien waivers are either conditional (effective only when payment clears) or unconditional (effective immediately upon signing regardless of payment status).

questions.question: Within what timeframe must a mechanics lien typically be filed after last providing labor or materials?
questions.explanation: Mechanics lien filing deadlines vary by state, typically ranging from 60-90 days after last furnishing labor or materials. Missing the deadline forfeits lien rights.

questions.question: After filing a mechanics lien, what must typically be done to enforce it?

options.text: File a lawsuit to foreclose within the statutory period

questions.explanation: A mechanics lien must be enforced through a foreclosure lawsuit filed within the statutory period (typically 6-12 months). Failure to do so releases the lien.

questions.question: What is a stop notice?

options.text: A notice to a lender or owner to withhold funds

questions.explanation: A stop notice (available in some states) notifies the construction lender or owner to withhold funds sufficient to satisfy the claimant's demand.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of contractor licensing?

options.text: To generate revenue for the state
To protect the public from unqualified contractors

questions.explanation: Contractor licensing exists primarily to protect consumers by ensuring contractors meet minimum standards of competence, financial responsibility, and character.

questions.question: Contracting without a license when one is required can result in:

options.text: Criminal penalties, fines, and inability to collect payment

questions.explanation: Unlicensed contracting can result in criminal misdemeanor or felony charges, substantial fines, and loss of the right to collect payment for work performed.

questions.question: An unlicensed contractor typically:

options.text: Cannot recover payment through the courts in most states
Can sue but not be sued

questions.explanation: In most states, an unlicensed contractor cannot use the courts to collect payment for work requiring a license. This is a significant penalty for unlicensed work.

questions.question: Which work typically does NOT require a contractor's license?

options.text: A homeowner improving their own residence

questions.explanation: Most states exempt homeowners who perform work on their own primary residence. However, building codes and permit requirements still apply.

questions.question: What is a Responsible Managing Employee (RME)?

options.text: A licensed individual who qualifies the contractor license for a company

questions.explanation: An RME is a qualified individual whose license and experience allow a company to hold a contractor's license. They are responsible for the company's compliance.

questions.question: Which business structure provides personal liability protection while allowing pass-through taxation?
questions.explanation: An LLC provides limited liability protection for owners while typically allowing profits and losses to pass through to individual tax returns without corporate taxation.

questions.question: In a sole proprietorship, the owner is:

options.text: Personally liable for all business debts and claims

questions.explanation: A sole proprietor has unlimited personal liability. Business creditors can pursue the owner's personal assets to satisfy business debts.

questions.question: What document establishes the operating rules for an LLC?
questions.explanation: An Operating Agreement governs how an LLC is run, including member rights, profit distribution, and management responsibilities.

questions.question: What is an employer's responsibility regarding employee payroll taxes?

options.text: Withhold taxes and submit to federal and state agencies

questions.explanation: Employers must withhold federal income tax, Social Security, and Medicare from employee wages and submit these along with employer portions to tax agencies.

questions.question: What IRS form do independent contractors receive instead of a W-2?
questions.explanation: Independent contractors receiving $600 or more receive IRS Form 1099-NEC (Nonemployee Compensation) instead of Form W-2 used for employees.

questions.question: Which factor indicates a worker is an employee rather than an independent contractor?

options.text: Company controls how the work is performed

questions.explanation: IRS uses control tests to determine worker status. If the company controls how work is done (not just the result), the worker is likely an employee.

questions.question: Misclassifying employees as independent contractors can result in:

options.text: Penalties, back taxes, and legal liability

questions.explanation: Misclassification can result in back payment of taxes, penalties, interest, and liability for benefits the worker should have received.

questions.question: What is termination for convenience?

options.text: Owner's right to terminate without cause if contract allows

questions.explanation: Termination for convenience allows the owner to end the contract without the contractor being in default. The contractor is paid for work completed plus reasonable termination costs.

questions.question: What is termination for cause?

options.text: Termination due to the contractor's failure to perform

questions.explanation: Termination for cause occurs when the contractor substantially fails to perform per the contract. The contractor may be liable for additional costs to complete the work.

questions.question: Before terminating a contractor for cause, the owner typically must:

options.text: Provide written notice and opportunity to cure

questions.explanation: Most contracts require written notice of default and a cure period (typically 7-14 days) before the owner can terminate for cause.

questions.question: What is mediation?

options.text: A non-binding process where a neutral third party helps resolve disputes

questions.explanation: Mediation is a voluntary, non-binding dispute resolution process where a neutral mediator helps parties reach a mutually acceptable agreement.

questions.question: What is arbitration?

options.text: A binding decision by a neutral arbitrator or panel

questions.explanation: Arbitration is a dispute resolution process where an arbitrator hears evidence and makes a binding decision. It's often faster and less formal than litigation.

questions.question: What is a notice of claim?

options.text: Written notification that a party intends to seek additional time or compensation

questions.explanation: A notice of claim formally notifies the other party of circumstances that may result in a claim for additional time or money. Timely notice is usually required to preserve claim rights.

questions.question: What is an excusable delay?

options.text: A delay caused by the contractor
A delay outside the contractor's control that may extend the contract time
A delay that shortens the schedule
A delay that has no effect

questions.explanation: An excusable delay is caused by events beyond the contractor's control (weather, owner changes, unforeseen conditions). It typically entitles the contractor to a time extension.

questions.question: A compensable delay entitles the contractor to:

options.text: Both time extension and additional compensation

questions.explanation: A compensable delay (usually caused by the owner) entitles the contractor to both a time extension AND additional compensation for extended general conditions.

questions.question: What is liquidated damages?

options.text: A pre-agreed daily amount assessed for late completion

questions.explanation: Liquidated damages are a pre-determined amount (typically per day) that the contractor pays if the project is not completed on time. It must reasonably estimate actual damages.

questions.question: What is an express warranty in construction?

options.text: An automatic warranty implied by law
A specific warranty stated in the contract

questions.explanation: An express warranty is specifically stated in the contract documents, such as a one-year warranty on workmanship.

questions.question: What is an implied warranty?

options.text: A warranty that exists by law even if not stated

questions.explanation: Implied warranties exist by operation of law, such as the implied warranty of habitability or the implied warranty of workmanlike construction.

questions.question: What is an indemnification clause?

options.text: A provision where one party agrees to protect another from liability

questions.explanation: An indemnification clause requires one party to protect (hold harmless) another party from certain claims or losses, often related to the indemnitor's work.

questions.question: A 'pay-when-paid' clause means:

options.text: The general contractor pays the sub within a reasonable time after receiving payment

questions.explanation: A pay-when-paid clause ties subcontractor payment to the GC receiving payment, but typically doesn't excuse payment indefinitely - a reasonable time limit applies.

questions.question: A 'pay-if-paid' clause means:

options.text: The subcontractor is only paid if the GC receives payment from the owner

questions.explanation: A pay-if-paid clause makes the GC's receipt of owner payment a condition precedent to paying the sub. It shifts the risk of owner non-payment to subcontractors.

questions.question: What is a flow-down clause in a subcontract?

options.text: A clause that binds the sub to the same terms as the prime contract

questions.explanation: A flow-down clause incorporates prime contract terms into the subcontract, binding the subcontractor to the same obligations as the general contractor.

questions.question: What is bid shopping?

options.text: Using one subcontractor's price to negotiate a lower price from another

questions.explanation: Bid shopping is the unethical practice of disclosing a sub's bid to competitors to get a lower price. It undermines fair competition and trust.

questions.question: What is bid peddling?

options.text: A subcontractor voluntarily lowering their price to beat competitors

questions.explanation: Bid peddling occurs when a subcontractor voluntarily approaches a GC to lower their price after learning they weren't the low bidder. Like bid shopping, it's considered unethical.

questions.question: A contractor discovers a significant error in the architect's plans. What should they do?

options.text: Ignore it and build as shown
Notify the owner or architect immediately
Fix it and add a change order later
Wait until the error causes problems

questions.explanation: Contractors have an obligation to promptly notify the owner/architect of discovered errors, inconsistencies, or omissions in the contract documents.

questions.question: What is AIA Document A201?

options.text: The General Conditions of the Contract for Construction

questions.explanation: AIA A201 is the General Conditions document that establishes the rights, responsibilities, and relationships of the parties throughout construction.

questions.question: What is AIA Document A101?

options.text: The Standard Form of Agreement Between Owner and Contractor (Stipulated Sum)

questions.explanation: AIA A101 is the standard Owner-Contractor Agreement for projects where the contract sum is a stipulated (fixed) amount.

questions.question: What is AIA Document G702?
questions.explanation: AIA G702 is the Application and Certificate for Payment form used by contractors to request progress payments.

questions.question: What is an Invitation to Bid (ITB)?

options.text: A request for contractors to submit competitive bids

questions.explanation: An Invitation to Bid (ITB) is a solicitation by an owner seeking competitive bids from contractors for a defined scope of work.

questions.question: What is a Request for Proposal (RFP)?

options.text: A request for a fixed price bid
A request that allows consideration of factors beyond just price

questions.explanation: An RFP allows the owner to evaluate proposals based on multiple factors (qualifications, approach, price) rather than just the lowest price.

questions.question: What is an addendum in the bidding process?

options.text: A written change to bid documents issued before bid opening

questions.explanation: An addendum is a written modification to the bidding documents issued before bid opening to clarify, correct, or change the original documents.

questions.question: What is a bid protest?

options.text: A formal challenge to the bidding process or award decision

questions.explanation: A bid protest is a formal written challenge to the conduct of a bidding process or the award decision, typically filed by an unsuccessful bidder.

questions.question: What is a 'responsive' bid?

options.text: A bid that meets all requirements of the bid documents

questions.explanation: A responsive bid conforms to all material requirements of the bidding documents including forms, signatures, bond requirements, and acknowledgment of addenda.

questions.question: What is a 'responsible' bidder?

options.text: A bidder capable of performing the contract satisfactorily
Any bidder who submits on time
A bidder with a local office

questions.explanation: A responsible bidder has the capability (experience, equipment, finances, personnel) to successfully perform the contract.

questions.question: What is a joint check agreement?

options.text: A payment made jointly to the contractor and supplier/sub to ensure payment

questions.explanation: A joint check agreement requires payment checks to include both the contractor and the subcontractor/supplier, ensuring the lower-tier party receives payment.

questions.question: What is a Schedule of Values?

options.text: A breakdown of the contract sum by work items for payment purposes

questions.explanation: The Schedule of Values allocates the contract sum among work categories. It's the basis for calculating progress payments and must equal the total contract price.

questions.question: Who certifies the contractor's application for payment?
questions.explanation: The architect reviews the contractor's application for payment and, if satisfied, certifies the amount due to the owner for payment.

questions.question: What must typically be submitted before final payment?

options.text: Lien waivers, warranties, as-builts, and closeout documents

questions.explanation: Final payment requires submission of final lien waivers, warranties, as-built drawings, operation manuals, and other closeout documents.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a 'time is of the essence' clause?

options.text: To make the completion date a material term subject to damages for delay

questions.explanation: A 'time is of the essence' clause makes timely performance a material contract term, allowing the non-breaching party to claim damages or terminate for delays.

questions.question: Why is proper written notice important in construction contracts?

options.text: Failure to give proper notice can waive rights to claims

questions.explanation: Most contracts require written notice within specified timeframes to preserve rights. Failure to give proper notice can result in waiver of claims for time or money.

questions.question: What is a Type I differing site condition?

options.text: Conditions different from those indicated in the contract documents

questions.explanation: Type I differing site conditions are physical conditions actually encountered that differ materially from those shown in the contract documents.

questions.question: What is a Type II differing site condition?

options.text: Unusual conditions not reasonably anticipated by an experienced contractor

questions.explanation: Type II differing site conditions are unknown physical conditions of an unusual nature that differ materially from those ordinarily encountered in the area.

questions.question: What is force majeure?

options.text: Unforeseeable circumstances that prevent contract fulfillment

questions.explanation: Force majeure refers to extraordinary events (acts of God, war, natural disasters) beyond the parties' control that may excuse performance or extend time.

questions.question: What is 'scope creep'?

options.text: Gradual expansion of project scope without formal authorization

questions.explanation: Scope creep is the gradual, uncontrolled expansion of project requirements without corresponding adjustments to time, budget, or resources.

questions.question: What is license reciprocity?

options.text: Getting a license in multiple trades
One state recognizing another state's contractor license
Sharing a license with a partner

questions.explanation: Reciprocity allows a contractor licensed in one state to obtain a license in another state without meeting all normal requirements, based on similar standards.

questions.question: What is overhead in construction estimating?

options.text: Indirect costs not directly attributable to a specific project

questions.explanation: Overhead includes indirect costs like office rent, utilities, administrative salaries, insurance, and other general business expenses not tied to specific jobs.

questions.question: What is the difference between direct and indirect costs?

options.text: Direct costs are specifically attributable to a project; indirect costs are not
Direct costs are fixed; indirect are variable

questions.explanation: Direct costs (labor, materials, equipment) can be specifically assigned to a project. Indirect costs (overhead) benefit multiple projects and the business generally.

questions.question: What is a contingency in a construction estimate?

options.text: An allowance for unforeseen conditions or changes

questions.explanation: A contingency is a percentage or dollar amount included in estimates to cover unforeseen costs, changes, or risks not specifically accounted for elsewhere.

questions.question: What is an allowance in a construction contract?

options.text: A sum included for items not yet selected or specified

questions.explanation: An allowance is a sum included in the contract for materials, equipment, or finishes that haven't been selected yet. Actual costs are reconciled against the allowance.

questions.question: What is assignment of a contract?

options.text: Transferring contract rights or obligations to another party

questions.explanation: Assignment is the transfer of contract rights or obligations to a third party. Most construction contracts prohibit assignment without written consent.

questions.question: What is privity of contract?

options.text: The legal relationship between parties who have entered into a contract

questions.explanation: Privity of contract is the legal relationship between contracting parties. Generally, only parties with privity can sue each other on the contract.

questions.question: What is a material breach of contract?

options.text: A significant failure that defeats the purpose of the contract

questions.explanation: A material breach is a substantial failure to perform that goes to the heart of the contract. It may excuse the other party's performance and allow termination.

questions.question: What damages can typically be recovered for breach of contract?

options.text: Compensatory damages to place the injured party in the position they would have been

questions.explanation: Contract damages are generally compensatory, designed to give the injured party the benefit of the bargain. Punitive damages are rarely available for breach of contract.

questions.question: What is the statute of limitations?

options.text: The time period within which a lawsuit must be filed

questions.explanation: The statute of limitations is the legally mandated timeframe within which a party must file a lawsuit. After expiration, the claim is typically barred.

questions.question: What is the statute of repose?

options.text: A time limit on construction defect claims measured from completion

questions.explanation: The statute of repose sets an absolute time limit (often 10 years) for bringing construction defect claims, measured from substantial completion regardless of when the defect is discovered.

questions.question: What should a contractor do if they have a personal financial interest in a subcontractor being considered?

options.text: Disclose the conflict to the owner

questions.explanation: Contractors should disclose any conflicts of interest, including financial relationships with subcontractors, to maintain trust and allow the owner to make informed decisions.

questions.question: How long should construction business records typically be retained?

options.text: 7 years or longer, depending on record type
Records don't need to be kept

questions.explanation: Tax records should be kept at least 7 years. Project records should be retained beyond the statute of repose period (often 10+ years) for potential claims.

questions.question: What is a performance specification?

options.text: A specification naming a specific product
A specification describing required results without dictating methods

questions.explanation: A performance specification describes the required outcome or performance criteria without specifying the exact product, method, or procedure to achieve it.

questions.question: What is a prescriptive specification?

options.text: A specification detailing exact materials and installation methods

questions.explanation: A prescriptive (descriptive) specification defines the exact materials, products, and installation methods to be used, leaving little discretion to the contractor.

questions.question: What is a 'basis of design' product in specifications?

options.text: A specific product the design is based upon that sets the standard for substitutions

questions.explanation: The basis of design product is the specific product the designer used to develop the design. Substitutions must meet or exceed its performance characteristics.

questions.question: What is a shop drawing?

options.text: Detailed fabrication drawings prepared by the contractor or supplier

questions.explanation: Shop drawings are detailed drawings, diagrams, and schedules prepared by the contractor, subcontractor, or supplier to show how components will be fabricated and installed.

questions.question: Who is responsible for reviewing shop drawings for compliance with contract documents?

options.text: The contractor before submitting, then the architect

questions.explanation: The contractor must review submittals for compliance before forwarding to the architect. The architect's review checks general conformance with design intent.

questions.question: What are 'as-built' drawings?

options.text: Drawings showing the actual constructed conditions including all changes

questions.explanation: As-built (record) drawings document the actual constructed conditions, incorporating all changes, field modifications, and deviations from the original design.

questions.question: What is a punch list?

options.text: A list of minor items to be completed or corrected before final payment

questions.explanation: A punch list is a list of minor items to be completed or corrected before the project can be considered finally complete. It's typically prepared at substantial completion.

questions.question: What is the contractor's responsibility for defective work discovered after final payment?

options.text: Correct defective work per the warranty provisions

questions.explanation: The contractor remains responsible for correcting defective work discovered within the warranty period even after final payment has been made.
